Zootopia is an animated movie that seems far more interested in making sure you understand its message than in trusting you to enjoy the story. From early on, the film’s allegory for racism is pushed so hard it stops being allegory and starts feeling like a checklist. Every conflict exists to reinforce the same point, and characters regularly pause the momentum to restate the moral in plain terms. There’s little room for subtext, ambiguity, or audience interpretation. If you somehow missed the message the first time, don’t worry—the movie will repeat it again, slower, and with emphasis. What’s frustrating is that the world-building and premise are genuinely clever. But instead of letting themes emerge naturally, the film insists on guiding your reaction at every step. By the second half, the messaging becomes so overt and self-satisfied that it actively hurts watchability. It’s not offensive. It’s exhausting. A movie that mistakes repetition for depth and sincerity for insight.

La entrega número 55 de la franquicia de los clásicos animados de Disney vuelve a retomar el formato de películas protagonizadas por personajes animales. Algo que Disney había dejado de lado tras Bolt y Winnie The Pooh para dar más protagonismo a personajes humanos. Zootopia parece retomar la idea que se había visto en Chicken Little sobre un mundo donde sus habitantes son animales humanoides. A diferencia de aquella película, Zootopia tiene muchísimas mejoras. Lo primero que se puede apreciar es su animación y calidad visual que sigue cumpliendo los estándares de su etapa de animación CGI. Tangled y Frozen habían impulsado una nueva etapa con un uso del CGI que pudo transmitir el estilo de Disney a un formato más realista sin perder la esencia. Zootopia lo lleva a un nivel más alto por medio del diseño de los personajes. Mientras los escenarios tienen la misma estética de las películas anteriores, los personajes tienen un diseño que potencia más lo que Disney había intentado hacer en Chicken Little. En esa película y también en Dinosaur se podía apreciar una buena estructura de pelaje que sirvió más como un borrador de lo que vendría después. Con The Wild se pudo ofrecer animales más realistas, aunque apartándose del estilo Disney. Con Bolt ya se pudo encontrar un balance entre el estilo Disney y el estilo realista. Eso fue evolucionando en Tangled y Frozen hasta al fin llegar a Zootopia. En esta película se pudo alcanzar el punto máximo de crear personajes animados que se sintieran como seres de carne y hueso. El pelaje de los personajes es lo que les da ese realismo que se quería alcanzar y tienen una estructura bastante detallada que consigue que los personajes tengan ese balance entre lo caricaturesco y lo realista. La película alcanza ese punto máximo que se quiso conseguir en las primeras películas CGI de Disney. La excelente animación no es lo único que hace de Zootopia una gran película. Su historia puede parecer algo sencilla y se aferra al estricto de reglamento de ser una película infantil. Pero existen sub textos que un adulto puede identificar y que la culminan como una de las obras definitivas de esta franquicia animada. La película presenta un mundo donde mamíferos de distintas especies evolucionaron hasta volverse más humanos y crear una sociedad propia. La protagonista Judy Hopps sueña con ser una gran policía que brinde seguridad y haga su aporte para crear un mejor mundo. Su llegada a su Zootopia y su misión de encontrar a Mr. Emmitt Ottterton dan inicio a varios momentos donde Judy descubre que la realidad es más difícil de lo que parece. Con esto la película transmite muchos mensajes ocultos sobre la humanidad y la sociedad. Lo primero que se puede notar es que los personajes están divididos en los grupos denominados Prey y Predator. En la ciudad de Zootopia, ambos supuestamente conviven pacíficamente, pero hay momento que muestran que no todo es así. Judy es subestimada por ser una coneja mientras los demás policías son animales que la superan en fuerza y tamaño. Al inicio se muestra que también ha sido subestimada por ello y por eso a sus padres les preocupa que ella sea policía. Nick Wilde es un zorro que acepto ser aquello que los demás piensan que solo los zorros hacen. Nick tuvo una infancia difícil donde no cumplió sus sueños debido a que los demás lo juzgaron por ser un zorro. En vez de demostrar que podía ser diferente, decidió aceptar eso que los demás dicen que es. El primer mensaje que la película aborda con estos momentos es la discriminación y los prejuicios. Disney ya tocó este tema en Pocahontas y The Hunchback Of Notre Dame, pero ahora lo lleva al contexto de la sociedad actual. Cuando Judy conoce a Nick en la heladería, piensa que por ser un zorro está causando un problema, pero ve que parece estar sufriendo una situación de discriminación por cómo el elefante heladero le niega atenderlo por ser un zorro. La cosa se pone más compleja cuando Judy descubre que sus sospechas sobre Nick al principio fueron acertadas. Al principio Judy lo usa por medio del chantaje para cumplir su misión, pero ambos se van dando cuenta de que son iguales en astucia e inteligencia. La película toca el tema de los prejuicios de una manera bastante compleja. Judy cree que todos los animales pueden ser quienes quieran ser, pero también tiene un prejuicio hacia los zorros debido a su experiencia con Gideon. Nick también es de los que subestima a Judy al principio por ser una coneja. Incluso Benjamin Clawhauser la llama tierna a Judy cuando la conoce por primera vez y ella dice no sentirse cómoda cuando animales de otras especies le dicen eso. Es una clara referencia a que a una persona negra le incomoda que alguien de otra raza lo llame así. El estereotipo es un tema que también juega un papel en la película porque forma parte de los prejuicios que se pueden tener hacia alguien perteneciente a un grupo específico. Nick resulta ser un estafador y Judy una coneja ingenua por lo que sucede más adelante. Esto demuestra que los estereotipos pueden tener razón y los prejuicios pueden ser acertados, ya que la idea que se tiene sobre un grupo específico surge por una razón. Pero los estereotipos y los prejuicios pueden a la vez ser erróneos debido a que Nick tuvo una infancia difícil y Judy demuestra tener una fortaleza más allá de su apariencia. Así que existen dos caras cuando se trata de evaluar a un individuo por su apariencia. El punto en común que hay entre Nick y Judy es que son muy listos y fueron menospreciados en el pasado. La película no se limita a tocar la discriminación solo por medio de los prejuicios y los estereotipos. También recurre a un tema central que es crucial y que incluso fue parte importante de la colonización de América. El primer indicio es un diálogo de Gideon que dicta que la naturaleza depredadora yace en el ADN, pero la clave más fundamental es uno de los diálogos de Mr. Big. Dice que los animales han evolucionado hasta alcanzar su etapa humana, pero en el fondo siguen siendo salvajes. La idea que la película va dando es que el comportamiento agresivo de los Predators se debe a su instinto natural y a un factor biológico. Algo que también se aplica perfectamente a los seres humanos. A pesar de que se considera algo pseudocientífico, la idea de que el comportamiento violento se debe al instinto natural siempre fue cierta. Dado que el ser humano pertenece al reino animal, es un hecho que los humanos también son animales. Por ende, poseen un instinto natural que impulsa el comportamiento violento y lascivo. Según los estudios científicos, eso se le atribuye al cerebelo reptiliano y las hormonas, factores biológicos. Los factores sociales no siempre son los causantes porque solo logran reprimir ese instinto o hasta detonarlo. En el caso de Zootopia, la planta crocus. Algo que puede ser un equivalente a un estimulante o una sustancia que active el lado salvaje del individuo. Así que la idea de que el comportamiento violento se atribuye a un instinto natural o un factor biológico siempre fue correcta y las ciencias sociales se equivocaron al afirmar lo contrario. Lo que la película hace con esto es una clara referencia al darwinismo social, que en parte siempre tuvo razón, pero tenía una trampa. En la película muestra cómo esta idea de que los Predators son salvajes por naturaleza impulsa los prejuicios hacia estos seres. Esto es una alegoría a los efectos negativos del darwinismo social cómo la justificación de la esclavitud y la segregación. Aunque la discriminación existía desde más antes por cuestiones culturales, fue con el darwinismo social que comenzó la discriminación por cuestiones biológicas. Algo que en la película está bien representado. Zootopia está incluso dividida en sectores que están hechos para grupos de animales en específico. Algo que puede interpretarse como una alusión a la segregación o los barrios que son ocupados por ciertas etnias como el barrio negro o el barrio chino. Al final Zootopia y sus habitantes no son diferentes a la sociedad humana. La película también tiene un giro impresionante que demuestra que el comportamiento salvaje no se limita a solo un grupo. También la mente maestra detrás demuestra que el verdadero mal puede yacer tras un rostro inocente que nadie sospecharía. Hay una ironía en el último giro dado que la película menciona un proyecto de inclusión que le dio a Judy la oportunidad de ser policía, pero solo para formar parte de algo que no se imaginaba. La ironía de esto es que es una alusión a como la idea de la inclusión puede ser usada por alguien que no le importa la causa y solo busca un beneficio propio. Zootopia termina teniendo un mensaje social bastante aferrado a la realidad. La moraleja que quiere dejar es que todos podemos coexistir si dejamos de lado nuestras diferencias y aceptamos que somos iguales como personas. Aunque es una buena enseñanza, la realidad es que los humanos nunca estuvieron destinados a vivir en harmonía y por eso la desigualdad sigue prevaleciendo. Lo menos que se puede hacer es intentar llevarse bien con los demás así como Judy y Nick pudieron entablar un lazo sin importar sus diferencias. De todas las películas que esta franquicia de clásicos Disney ha producido en la década de los 2010, Zootopia es sin duda la mejor de todas. Es una gran película debido a su lado artístico y también a su mensaje social. Tiene puntos interesantes que se pueden encontrar en el terreno sociológico, antropológico y positivista. Es una película infantil que sabe plantear una buena reflexión sobre la sociedad y la desigualdad. Mi calificación final para esta película es un 10/10.

Satisfying. I begin watching 'Zootopia' without much interest, unable to detect elements that truly catch my attention. The introduction of Nick Wilde (Jason Bateman) brings a completely different rhythm, with a presence that fills the screen. From that moment on, the story finds the right pace. The ensemble of characters serves solely to move the plot forward; they are merely tools for stitching the narrative together. The protagonists, Judy (Ginnifer Goodwin) and Nick (Jason Bateman), are the ones who carry all the emotional and narrative weight. They bring dynamism, memorable moments, and establish the essential connection with the audience. The plot feels slow at times, yet it remains interesting and enjoyable. The humor is well integrated and works for all audiences. It is one of those animated films that clearly embraces its identity as animation: it does not aim for realism but instead defines its characteristics with precision. It conveys a clear message of personal growth, showing that even when you feel out of place, it is still possible to carve out your own path. Behind all this is a team of writers, screenwriters, and directors capable of delivering a fresh, balanced, and well-crafted story. It is pleasant to watch. A highly recommended option within this genre, ideal for those seeking entertainment without overcomplicating things.

★★★★☆ Zootopia is that rare animated movie that works brilliantly as both a hilarious buddy-cop comedy for kids and a surprisingly sharp, layered allegory about prejudice, systemic bias, and the danger of fear-based politics for adults. The world-building is absolutely off the charts: a sprawling, fully realized metropolis where every district (from icy Tundratown to rainy Rainforest District) feels alive, detailed, and logically designed for animals of every size. The gag density is insane (the sloth DMV scene is still one of the funniest things ever animated), and the action sequences (especially the naturalist club chase and the climactic train fight) are genuinely thrilling. Judy Hopps is an all-timer protagonist: tiny, relentlessly optimistic, and forced to confront her own unconscious biases in ways that feel honest and earned. Nick Wilde’s slow journey from cynical hustler to proud cop is pure charm, and Ginnifer Goodwin and Jason Bateman have chemistry that leaps off the screen. Shakira’s "Try Everything" over the end credits still gives goosebumps every single time. It loses half a star only because the third-act "big twist" is a little convoluted and the villain’s motive feels a touch undercooked compared to the rest of the film’s nuance. Four stars: one for the laughs, one for the heart, one for the world you never want to leave, and one because it somehow made a story about predator-prey relations feel urgently relevant without ever preaching. Smart, gorgeous, endlessly rewatchable comfort food with a brain. 8/10. Welcome to Zootopia—population: one of the best animated movies of the 2010s. 🐰🦊🏙️❤️

Zootopia is a smart, engaging, and visually stunning animated film that deserves a solid 9 out of 10. It blends comedy, heart, and action with a thoughtful message. The story follows Judy Hopps, an optimistic bunny cop, and Nick Wilde, a sly fox con artist, as they uncover a conspiracy in the city of Zootopia. The Best Film Of The Year, So Far. From the studio that brought you Tangled, Wreck-It Ralph, Frozen & Big Hero 6, Zootopia surfaces as a highly original, incredibly refreshing, thoroughly engaging, surprisingly timely & delightfully subversive beast fable about prejudice & stereotype that not only marks a new creative high for Disney but is arguably the finest film that this legendary animation studio has come up with in their Revival Era, so far. Set in a world inhabited by anthropomorphic animals, the story of Zootopia takes place in the titular metropolis and follows a bunny cop named Judy Hopps who, despite her par excellent performance in the class, is assigned parking duty by her superior. But when she volunteers to undertake a missing-predator case, she is given 48 hours to solve the mystery or resign, following which she blackmails a sly fox into helping her, and uncovers a sinister conspiracy. Co-directed by Byron Howard & Rich Moore, the duo put up an intriguing world on the screen that does have a fresh quality but there is still a deep sense of familiarity to it. However, where the two leave a lasting impression is in finding that perfect balance between its consistently gripping storyline & moments of pure hilarity. The writing staff also deserves a mention, for their screenplay brims with numerous pop culture references, parodies many renowned classics & handles its topical themes with care. The 3D animation is absolutely top-notch, for the images retain its crispness, clarity & vibrancy from beginning to end. The animators put up a vast number of characters on the screen, ranging from the largest elephant to the smallest shrew, yet they are all given a well-defined arc. Cinematography further enhances the overall look n feel of the story with its fluid camera-work, splendid use of colour palette & spot-on lighting. Editing provides just enough screen time to all the relevant characters while moving the plot forward at a blistering pace. The cast is wisely chosen, and all the actors do a competent job in lending their voice & soul to the mammals they play. Ginnifer Goodwin brings a bubbly side to the new cop in town and confidently plays her role. Jason Bateman plays his part with finesse plus his voice really fits his cynical con artist character. Also, the chemistry between the two is a highlight in itself. Michael Giacchino's ebullient score seamlessly blends in & compliments the narrative while Shakira beautifully wraps everything up with a catchy, uplifting & wonderful song that smartly summarises its themes & message. On an overall scale, Zootopia finds Disney stepping out of its comfort zone to tackle a bold, ambitious & risky project, and it is one gamble that pays off tremendously well in the studio's favour. Also, its arrival couldn't have been better, considering how its elements of prejudice & stereotypes mirror the racial hostilities present in our very own current social environment. An ingenious blend of sophisticated storytelling, jubilant humour & thought-provoking themes that amazes, entertains & enlightens without ever compromising with the fun factor, Zootopia is a definite delight for viewers of all ages, and is undoubtedly the best film of the year, so far. Strongly recommended.

Normally I enjoy animated films because they're are usually visually stunning and that is enough to hold my attention. Some I love and some I just enjoy even if they are flawed. But I was fairly excited for this film so I watched it, because I'm a sucker for animated films, and I was absolutely blown away by this movie and it surpassed my expectations. Firstly, Zootropolis (or Zootopia depending where you come from) is much, much more than your generic Disney film. It will actually entertain a higher age demographic rather than younger kids due to it's exciting story and mature themes and because it is more a crime drama than a comedy. Yes, the directors and writers aren't afraid to explore much more darker and mature themes then they usually do and they do throw in a few jump worthy parts. On the other hand, the kids will probably enjoy seeing the animals speak but adults will be really engaged because of it's story. This film definitely deserved it's Academy Award Oscar for 'Best Animated Feature'. Secondly, this film had me hooked all the way through because of its detective and mysterious themes and its crime drama story, it's frequently humourous sequences and because the film had a surprising amount of an emotional weight towards it. Even though the tone is normally dark for an animated Disney film, the film still allows for some hilarious moments that, luckily, doesn't affect the overall tone. And like all modern Disney films, this film has stunning backdrops and top-notch animation and the soundtrack isn't half bad, either, alongside side it's exciting score. Furthermore, Zootropolis works well because of it's extremely likeable characters, who have emotional and sympathetic backstories, it's story, which is well paced, extremely well told and presented, and as the chemistry between Nick Wilde and Judy Hopps is rich and compelling because of it's well written dialogue and great casting choices including Idris Elba, Ginnifer Goodwin and Jason Bateman. Not only that but Zootropolis thrills in it's tension filled action sequences and due to it's shocking plot twists; Zootropolis also allows Godfather fans to be delighted as well. In the end, Zootropolis isn't your average animated film because it is much more than that, it has an extremely intriguing, unprecedented presence and a well told story and is aided by compelling characters and fun moments. Zootropolis not only sets a bar high for future animated films but is probably one the best animated films ever made as of 2016. Additionally, Zootropolis is also one of the most enjoyable family films ever made. I absolutely adore Zootropolis.

Zootropolis (Zootopia) was a part of my highly anticipated list of movies for this year. Sure, Deadpool looked amazing (and was, according to nearly everyone) and Batman V Superman was the NEXT BIG THING but there was just something about Zootropolis that made me so excited. After reviews started rolling in, it got me even more excited, Chris Stuckmann's review especially. (Link at the bottom of review) And now I finally got to watch it. And I can simply say that Zootropolis was...AMAZING! Oh by the way, this review is SPOILER FREE. The Story Zootropolis's story is about a passionate little bunny known as Judy Hopps. She wants to do good for the world and decides that she wants to be a cop. This isn't very common and many of the other animals show that but Judy thinks that everyone can be whoever they want to be. When she has her first case, she isn't given much so she teams up with a fox known as Nick Wilde to help her solve the case. I really like this story as Nick and Judy get to learn more about each other throughout the story and as well as that, it results in a really fun, family adventure. The Characters Oh my the characters. In my opinion, this is Zootropolis's strongest parts. They are just so likeable! And before I talk about them, I have to talk about how well the actors portray them. I think Ginnifer Goodwin did a brilliant job at voicing Judy and I haven't seen many movies with Jason Bateman as a voice of a character or a character but I think he did an excellent job as Nick. And I can't forget Idris Elba's performance as Chief Bogo (the one who gives out the cases) He nailed it. Alright, now what I thought about them. Judy Hopps and Nick Wilde steal the show completely. (well, they are the main characters)They both have strengths and weaknesses which show throughout the movie a lot and they do have some really funny, touching and quite crazy moments that I will not spoil. And even though Chief Bogo is that character who can be a bit of a jerk at the beginning, you come to see him from a different perspective when the movie goes on. There are many more characters that do a really good job but this section is already too big. On to the animation. The Animation As usual, Disney did a great job with the animation. The action scenes look great, the visuals are fantastic and the city itself is huge. I may now sound like i'm doing a video game review but i'm not. The city is beautiful with flying colors. (quite literally actually) So yeah, they did a really good job, as usual. The Comedy If you watch Chris Stuckmann's Review, he says that: "It is more focused on it's story then making you laugh. And that's something I loved about it." And I agree. I think the story is brilliant and because of it, when the jokes come up, there actually hilarious. The comedy is focused around children and adults so of course, there will be jokes where only the adults will laugh or only the children. According to other reviewers, the scene with "Mr Big" was paying homage to: "The Godfather." And even though I haven't seen The Godfather, the whole scene was really funny. This goes to show you what you're going to expect. And here's the final part of the review... The Serious Note/ The Message Now is when I talk to you about the serious note. This movie focuses on so many different subjects you don't think a Disney movie would ever cover. I actually quite like it because it adds a little more originality to it. If you have ever watched Happy Feet, it was trying to deliver a message. But the way they did was so childlike that it made it pointless for older kids or adults. But Zootopia did it with a more serious tone and a non forceful way that it really delivered it well. The Grade I love Zootropolis. It's message is brought well, it's animation is great, it's characters are awesome, it's comedy is hilarious, it's story is brilliant and it's serious tone makes it even better. This movie is defiantly 100% worth watching and i'm going to give it an A+ Chris Stuckmann's Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Du7wcFPBfIE

Zootopia is the 30th highest grossing film of all time, and the fourth animated film to pass $1 billion in global box-office earnings. Judy Hopps, the determined and enthusiastic main character, decides she wants better for herself, even when something else is expected. She faces many hardships as she realizes that creating a different reality for herself will be a lot harder than she first believed. Her difficulties point to the fact that she is a female, and a smaller prey species. In the end, Judy is successful in creating the change that she had been wanting for so long. Zootopia was created to teach people of all ages that goals and dreams can be reached through hard work and determination, no matter what circumstances they may be in. The directors were successful in getting the point across. This essay will analyze the use of irony, symbolism, and a great storyline to show evidence of the creators purpose throughout the film. The directors of Zootopia waste no time in presenting situational irony in the beginning. The main characters are introduced, and we meet Judy Hopps. She is a small bunny with a very large family, and two carrot farmers for parents. She is literally at the "bottom of the food chain" in her society. The ironic part of the situation is that she wants to become a police officer. In her world, this workforce is comprised only of large male animals. The creators do this to immediately place her in a position where she is at a disadvantage. To the viewers, her wish to become a cop is almost comical, and the task seems impossible because of her situation. In the end, however, Judy does become a police officer. She not only becomes a cop, she ends up being one of the most successful ones who solves a huge mystery case. The overall story is a testament that if Judy can turn her life around, anyone can. Symbolism is also included in the movie, and it is one of the most powerful tools used in the film to convey the creator's purpose. The characters present in the movie represent many different types of people in the real world. The wide variety of animal species shown in the film are meant to represent the different races, social classes, intelligence levels, etc.., that are present in today's world. The directors do this to give viewers the ability to connect with certain characters that they might be similar to in reality. This is meant to empower the minds of young viewers as they watch the actions of the characters that they connect with. They see them working hard to set goals, and successfully achieve them. This leaves people with a healthy mindset and a hope that they can always better themselves, no matter the circumstances. The overall story itself is another way the point is made. Judy's life and work are anything but easy, and she is constantly dealing with new challenges. She stays optimistic and hopeful for most of the movie, but there is one instance where she finds herself wanting to give up because of the hardships she is facing. These details are crucial to the development of the main idea because it shows viewers how to deal with problems in a healthy way, while maintaining a good attitude. On the other hand, it also shows that the road will be tough, and there will be times where quitting will sound like the best option. Judy does not give up though, and we see her push forward and succeed in the end. Some people think that Zootopia is simply just a kid movie made to do nothing but entertain young children. While the story is animated and easy enough for kids to understand, it has way too many good messages in it to be considered just a kids movie. It teaches things in a way that people of all ages can understand, but the messages taught are very beneficial for people to learn at a young age and carry with them for the rest of their lives. Zootopia is a great film that everyone must see at some point in life. The lessons of hard work and determination are presented through a variety of tools that definitely get the point across to the viewers of the movie. It does this while also remaining exciting and entertaining for young children to enjoy. Judy Hopps is placed in a tough situation, but leaves it successful and strong. Her journey captivates the hearts and minds of many and gives the opportunity for viewers to be inspired by her success and character. The directors want everyone to know that it doesn't matter if a journey has a less than great start. The only thing that matters is that the goal is reached and that there was something learned from the process of getting there.

I'm actually a bit surprised Disney took a stab at a movie with this kind of weight. Maybe it's because I watched Hidden Figures yesterday or that headlines each day remind me of the great dichotomy of "us vs. them..." Zootopia is a movie about race, and I don't expect it to be the last one I watch in this year's Academy lineup. Rather than addressing race on, Zootopia is wise in the way many newer Disney movies have made commentary through analogy. "Predators versus prey" is something we teach all children, but framing race as Zootopia does allows parents to have a much-needed discussion with the next generation of global citizens. It's especially poignant that in this classic crime story, the case - and the racial inequality - is solved by small-town residents unaware that their own actions have a meaningful impact on the equality of the world. Like I said, hats off to Disney. As a nominee for the Best Animated category, it's still too early to say if Zootopia has the chops to take out its Disney sibling Moana or the other movies on the list. There are some stunning examples of animation, especially with falling rain, waterfalls, and other liquids - that's one area of animation I often forget is animated. It's hard not to fall in love with each character in Zootopia, and the animation does everything to support (and nothing to detract) from that process as a member of the audience. Though it seems like a bit of a sleeper among their animated lineup (especially with the early March 2016 release it had), I'm excited that Zootopia will get seen by a few more children - and a few more adults - as a result of its nomination. Zootopia will probably end up on my shelf when I have kids, if only for how well it handles race relations. I'm still wondering whether I'm 'predator' or 'prey,' and if I even want to be.

I didn't know what to think about this movie before I saw it. There was so much hype I was afraid to be disappointed. All I knew was that it was highly anticipated, and when it came out people went crazy for it. Critics and audiences alike loved this movie for being "real," and coming out at "just the right time in America." This was mainly due to the fact that film talks a lot about race, while not talking directly about race. You see, it's like Paddington, Babar, or Curious George in that way. It talks about race, but only through animals. So it's not actually portraying people of color, but using anthropomorphic creatures to do so. The movie would have been so much more effective if they animated people of color and the institutions which keep white people privileged. But they don't. Instead it's incredibly confusing when it comes to who are the haves, and who are the have nots. They may have done this to be ambiguous in order to show that many people are intersectional, but because they're animals, it doesn't really work that way. Like do black sheep have different standards and societal expectations than white sheep? The animal allegory doesn't work unless they're all the same animal because it literally shows us that races are different species (eugenics), when that isn't true. Lastly, you can map out the plot from a mile away. So let's dive into the good, the bad and the ugly, with Zootopia. Very simply put, the movie is about a rabbit and a fox. The rabbit, named Judy, wants to be a cop. But because she's a prey animal and also a woman - they don't really address gender that much, but for the sake of this review, I will - she's not supposed to be a cop, she's supposed to remain a little farm bunny. But like most Disney female characters she wants more than "this provincial life," so she moves to Zootopia, a utopian city where prey and predator live together in harmony. This of course isn't true as Judy soon finds out. She faces prejudice as a prey animal at work and in the city, but decides to take her destiny in her own paws. She tackles a huge who done it mystery case and teams up with a criminal fox, Nick, and the unlikely duo solves the crime. The villain (spoilers) turns out to be a white sheep, a seemingly innocent prey animal. All in all, the moral is, looks can be deceiving, and anyone can be whatever they want to be, no matter what society says. I love the land of Zootopia. I think it's so creative how they make a Sahara part, a jungle part, a tundra part, and even a tiny rodent village. That's awesome! But aside from a few scenes, they don't really show much of the city. I also don't like how the animal allegory has so many plot holes. And this is mainly because the movie uses animals instead of people! Lastly, Shakira and Judy are constantly sexualized. The villain is obvious and the movie is long. Sitting through the misunderstanding between Nick and Judy was agonizing. So, the racial allegory, does it do its job? No. I was constantly confused in the movie if they were trying to confirm that reverse racism exists. Sometimes it seemed as though the prey were the people of color and the predators were white. This happens when Nick tries touching the sheep's hair and Judy says, "You know you can't just touch a sheep's wool." This is obviously mimicking real life, when you can't just go up and touch a black person's hair. Sometimes it makes it seem as though it's the other way around, and the prey are white and the people of color are predators. What the f*ck? This can be seen when the prey animals are trying to "civilize" the predators. The predators are thugs and "black." This can be seen with the jaguar who goes "savage" because savagery is a trait put on African Americans as well as indigenous people. So does that mean the prey is white and the people of color are predators? Maybe they're saying that the white people (prey) are actually the savages and taking a Pocahontas/Paddington route? I just don't know. And that's a problem because if the movie is going for a racial allegory, then it has to be clear. But instead it's muddled because Disney was too afraid to use people, so they used cute little animals to tell their "progressive" story. I also didn't like the comedic elements in the film. There was the nudist thing. Was that supposed to be funny? Animals not wearing clothes, ha-ha? Then The Godfather references were meh. It's been done before. Then of course you have the Disney/Pixar trope of juxtaposing an animal's size with the type of voice it has. In Zootopia, there's a small animal with a deep voice. It's similar to Up with the evil dog having a high pitched voice, or the cute baby form The Incredibles who is actually the devil. I'm TIRED OF IT. The other problematic part I have with the film is the sexualization of animals. I know they're supposed to be anthropomorphic and take on human qualities. But really, we're going give a bunny boobs and hips? We're going to sexualize Giselle -Shakira's character - by having the camera hold on her animal butt uncomfortably? These are animals! They're not sexy. Well, maybe they are to some people, but it's also adding to the sexualization of female characters. The men are not sexualized the same way the women are. In fact, the men are able to have a wide range of body types, while the females are given very little. But as for the main characters, Judy's body is much more "feminine" than Nick's. Nick just looks like a fox on his hind legs, but Judy is given curves, why, if not to titillate the presumably straight men watching it. I guess if I had to say something I liked about the film, it would have to be my favorite scene. I love the part where Judy is spying on Nick and discovers his undercover Popsicle scheme. It's really cool seeing different parts of the city, how his life works, and the different animals he meets. Nick, unlike Judy, rolls with his stereotype as the "sly fox." But this brings me to another problem, some animals fit into their stereotypes while others don't. Why is this? To create a wide range of characters, or for comedic effect? Ha-ha that animal doesn't fit into our expectations; therefore it's funny because they're different. I think the best example of this is the overweight cheetah who works the front desk at the Zootopia police department. He's a stereotypical fat, donut eating cop. But he's also fat, and a cheetah. Does that give his character depth? No, they just use him as a pawn to make some jokes with. There is a point where he has to move to the back of the office because predators are now scary, I don't know if he's supposed to be black or white here... he could be black because a lot of people in the human world discriminate against black people because they're not as universal as white people are. They're also seen as meaner and ruder. Therefore, why would you want one welcoming you at the front desk? Or could it be he's losing his white privilege? The movie doesn't make that very clear. So some animals fit into a stereotype, others don't (Judy). That fits in with the message that looks are deceiving, but sometimes looks are also true? Like cops eat donuts? The DMV are sloths? Also, in the end Nick and Judy get together, is that an allegory for an in interracial couple? Why didn't they just use real people? It would have been so much more effective. Also, if it is supposed to be a race allegory, can we tell what races/ethnicities the actors are by their voices? In my opinion, that's a common way people can make things seem "diverse." Of course it's impossible to know what race a person is by their voice, but it is used on the radio all the time to make their shows seem "diverse." Do you think it was used here? I knew the two leads were voiced by white people, I knew the Indian elephant was voiced by someone of Indian descent, and I knew that Mrs. Otterton was voiced by a black woman. I didn't know Chief Bogo was voiced by a black man however. This clearly shows that you can't tell what race people are by their voice, but that is the intention of some media, especially when the character is just a voice. And I think voice acting in animated shows use this trick too, in order to prove they have a diverse cast they may want to hire people with more of an 'accent' than others. And because of this, I was socialized to associate the hyenas from The Lion King, with black people. Thanks Disney. Overall, I just don't get it. I don't think the movie is ground breaking or diverse in anyway. I don't think the morals are very strong seeing that they're using animals to tell a human story. Wouldn't it have been stronger to tell it with real kids? Reflect real life with real people? Even CGI people would have been better than this. I give it a 7/10, and in my opinion, I'm being lenient.

"Disney: Hilariously Exploiting Stereotypes In Animal Form" Who would have thought that another Disney animation focused on the lives of animals would be such a hit? If you want to laugh, cry, be uplifted, and experience a myriad of emotions, then Zootopia is the movie for you. Kids will love the cute animals depicted throughout the movie, as well as childish humor that kids will giggle hysterically at. Moreover, adults will not struggle with keeping their attention focused on the movie, like most "Kid" movies, because of the amazing artistry and captivating plot. An astounding feat that the film accomplished is the teaching opportunity it took to discuss, for all ages, real world issues that we struggle with around the world today. From the tiny stature of a mob boss arctic shrew, Mr. Big, to the largest elephant yoga teacher, the metropolis of Zootopia is a place thought to be where all types of animals can live, thrive, and make their dreams come true. This is the case for a small town bunny name Judy Hopps (wonderfully voiced by Ginnifer Goodwin). Judy a determined and peppy rabbit with the inability to stop pursuing her dreams becomes the first bunny police officer in Zootopia. With the odds stacked against her, Officer Hopps takes on a curious case that will make or break her dreams and the metropolis of Zootopia. On her quest, Judy pairs up with an unimaginable partner, a con artist fox named Nick Wilde (brilliantly voiced by Jason Bateman). Together the unthinkable partners have to piece together clues to solve the mysterious case that could prove to be the end of the marvelous metropolis of Zootopia. The amazing plot of the movie takes on the difficult task to teach its viewers the complexities and blatant issues of the world that may or may not be easily noticed. For example, two true enemies in the animal kingdom, a fox and bunny, have to set aside their differences to make sure that their metropolis survives. How is this any different in the real human world today? One can take many approaches to this issue such as Republicans and Democrats working together, high-income citizens cooperating and working with low-income citizens, black and white Americans working together, and many other real life scenarios that cause conflict in the world. This issue between Nick Wilde and Judy Hopps teaches us that we have a choice to who we are and we can put aside our differences and work together harmoniously. A particular point in the film that demonstrated the stroke of genius from the directors is the incorporation of the DMV run by sloths. It is common knowledge that sloths are some of the slowest moving creatures on earth, and the DMV is one of the most frustrating government agencies because of their slothful nature in dealing with customers. This hilarious and outrageous portrayal in which officer Hopps has to struggle with a sluggish sloth when she is in a hurry to get pertinent information dealing with her case gives a classic representation of real world frustration that many have undergone. The simple yet complex features throughout the movie provide a stimulating and relatable story. As the movie progresses, an underlying issue is finally revealed that will shock the audience. The issue brought to light is that sometimes the real threat to an individual or society is not the predator in the relationship, but the conniving prey. The movie teaches us that we need to put our prejudices aside so we can make correct decisions based on actual evidence, rather than viewing things through biased lenses. This is a powerful message that is placed in the movie that demonstrates the calamity in the world, especially in the United States, because of previous historical issues that will not be put to rest. Directors Bryon Howard, Richard Moore, and Jared Bush put their minds together to create a unique reality in which animals endure the same small and large concerns that humans do. Some of which include dirty politics, racism, and the struggle to live harmoniously with people of all backgrounds. This fascinating parallel between skin color and animal variety shares a beautiful angle on the diversity of the world. With their creative perspective, the directors flawlessly incorporated other iconic films into Zootopia such as "The Godfather", "Who Framed Roger Rabbit", and many other classic films. This tasteful placement of themes of iconic films adds a subtle complexity that made the movie enjoyable to all age ranges. Walt Disney productions over the past few years have been impeccable, including Big Hero Six, Tangled, and the widely popular Frozen. Individuals that have seen these films understand the amazing results that all these movies have achieved, but many would conclude that they have reached the peak of their performance. These conclusions couldn't be more wrong because Zootopia is Disney's true masterpiece. I mean, come on, who wouldn't be interested in a film that hilariously exploits stereotypes and has a nudist colony for animals?

I can think of no other film that is as timely as this one. Though it's a typical Disney film in structure, the entire film is an overt allegory for racism... and how we each can do our part to overcome prejudice and adversity in society. The protagonist is little Judy Hopps, who aspires to become a police officer despite her diminutive bunny stature and country-bumpkin background. Judy is a great protagonist and worthy role model for little girls, or anybody really. The weird thing about her, and what makes this movie so different, is that she's a racist. She doesn't want to be, and tries very hard not to be, and the story follows her as she begins to realize her prejudices and works to overcome them. The overall message of inclusion and celebrating diversity is a timely and important one, and one that has never been so fully expressed in a children's film. The movie touches on some pretty sensitive racial and gender stereotypes, including some not-so-disguised Islamophobia. I said to myself "Damn, I can't believe they went there" more than once. So yeah, it does get a little heavy for a Disney film, but there is enough humor and action mixed in to lighten up the subject matter. Though the movie is clever, the writing is not inherently all that funny... most of the credit for the film's humor is due to the excellent work by the voice actors. Their delivery is really spot on and made me laugh out loud, notably Jason Bateman and Idris Elba (who I am really loving as a voice actor!!). Then there is the cutting-edge animation, which is truly amazing... you can see every hair on each body. It's pretty eye-popping. As a whole, it's no "Inside Out", but it's a thoughtful and meaningful addition to the Disney canon.

Zootopia (2016) - Has made a huge impact on a lot of people and at first I never understood why. I never thought the movie was going to be bad but I just didn't think that this would be the next big thing for Disney especially after their amazing lineup of films like "Tangled" and "Big Hero 6". However, when I finally saw the movie I was completely blown away and now I see why everyone loves this film so much. There were two things that stood out to me, one of them was the chemistry between Judy and Nick. They are probably one of the most irresistible Disney pairings since Rapunzel and Flynn Rider. I really loved the way they work off of each other as well as warming up to share their feelings. The other thing I loved is the way they establish the city of Zootopia itself. Through a clever use of imagery we see how Predators and Prey became what they are today. We also see the many districts that Zootopia has to offer and they take full advantage of showing of each and every one of them and how unique they are. The other part of the story includes a mystery that our heroes have to crack. The mystery only keeps getting bigger and bigger as the movie plays on and the places they visit all have a critical importance into bringing our characters closer to the final reveal. The side characters they meet along the way all have their memorable moments and some of them play important roles into cracking the case. The big thing that caught many people's attention was the morals of Racism and discrimination against others. It does go pretty deep when telling those messages and hits a homerun for a lot of people. I think the way they use Predator and Prey to teach that moral is genius and leads to a lot of heartfelt moments that did make me feel emotional from time to time. The animation is mind blowing and they capture the feeling of being in a big city while also adding features like size and scope to make Zootopia feel so universal to any size of mammal. The characters also look very Disney and it's very cool how each one of them is accurately sized like their real life counterparts. The music was done by Michael Giacchino. You may recognize him as the composer for many Pixar films like "Ratatouille" and "Inside out". The music features a lot of electric guitar beats and bass strums which really help embrace the feeling of big city life. Theres also a featured pop song by Shakira called "Try Everything" and it plays itself out as an inspirational song that really does fit the movie's theme and everything it stands for. My only nitpick would have to be the pace of the third act. It doesn't ruin anything and it's done great in terms of the story, but I felt like after coming off everything that happened in the 2nd act, it just felt a little off when things start to come back to together. Overall, I was surprised by this movie and it's probably one of the best that Disney has to offer. (A)

Zootopia: Bunny Cop to the Rescue Zootopia: Disney's best animated movie of 2016 is full of cheerful, courageous, and slightly disapproving characters who take you on a remarkable journey to save their beloved city, Zootopia. Early in the movie when Judy is seeing Zootopia for the first time you get an impression of what Zootopia really is. A city where racism does not exist and where diversity is accepted. Zootopia is the place where both predators and prey have evolved past their natural desire to kill each other and live in grace. Its charm results from the spectacular animation and witty script. Judy Hopps (perfectly voiced by Gennifer Goodwin) is a bunny who has her mind set on becoming the first female cop and move to the big city of Zootopia where she presumes to be just like the big city cops. Judy, who lives in a farm with her 275 brothers and sisters, gets no support from her parents who want her to stay and help build their business, but Judy, listening to her heart, follows her dreams. She goes through strenuous training and her hard work pays off because she finishes top of her class and she quickly decides to put her skills to good use and moves to the big city of Zootopia. She is immediately struck with the brutal truth of adult life where she has a depressing apartment. Judy reports to work and quickly becomes frustrated. No one takes her seriously because she is a tiny bunny. On her very first day she is assigned traffic duty. Her boss, Chief Bogo (Idris Elba) clearly has no faith in her and even shows signs of regrets when it came to hiring a female bunny. However that doesn't stop Judy Hopps. This film demonstrates that even when the world wants you to fail, if you believe in yourself you can achieve anything. This is why Zootopia is one of the best Disney movies ever made. When Judy is finally presented with a real case she has to uncover the truth behind the mysterious disappearance of mammals all over the city. She only has one clue though, a cunning fox named Nick (voice of Jason Bateman). The two set out on a wild, bizarre, dangerous mission to find out what is happening to the mammals of Zootopia. The film nailed the chemistry between Judy and Nick specifically when they find themselves in danger when they search for a paranoid and ominous panther named Mr. Manchas (voice by Jesse Corti). You just know that even when the movie takes some dark turns, nothing will separate the two. Zootopia demonstrates the values of true friendship and what teamwork can accomplish, as well as displaying what courage, faith, and commitment accomplish if you never give up. Furthermore, there is no targeted audience with this film because anyone at any age could benefit from watching a movie like this. The length of the movie is long enough to include all the details necessary and not leave people baffled because of unanswered questions. Another strong aspect of the film was the incredibly talented animation which included a touch of realism throughout the whole film and it did not go unnoticed since it won the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature. It's very much demonstrated with the features of the city and with the many different animal species, particularly when Judy was saying goodbye to her family and we get a glimpse of all of her siblings. Zootopia may not have the single alongs that Frozen has, but it's clever enough to catch your attention when personal resilience is so well demonstrated and captures your emotions so well. It conveys a message that are rarely seen in movies for children:Success is no accident. It's hard work, studying, learning, sacrifice and love for what you are doing.

Jason Bateman and Ginnifer Goodwin lend their voices in Disney's Zootopia. Zootopia is an area where all animals are able to live together in harmony. Goodwin is Judy Hoops, a young rabbit that has aspirations to be a cop. She is of course ridiculed as rabbits are typical farmers that are not aggressive. She aims high and graduates from school only to become stereotyped again by her Water buffalo boss (Idris Elba) who makes her become a meter maid. To demonstrate that she can offer more to the force, she takes on a missing otter case and agrees to solve the case within 48 hours or quit. With few leads and evidence, she has no choice but to have a cunning fox Nick Wilde (Jason Bateman) help her even though foxes are known for being mischievous and untrustworthy. As she investigates the case, she finds there is a strange occurrence where historical predators are becoming savage again. The She adds this mystery to the case and hopes to return Zootopia and make it safe for all animals again. Zootopia is above average animated film. The film offers enough humor for adults and the animation will likely dazzle young audiences alike. Many jokes rely on animals being stereotyped such as sloths for being slow and foxes being cunning. Bateman does a good job providing his sense of humor that will be appreciated by fans of his. Puns such as we need to address the elephant in the room, and there being a literal elephant in the room are also scattered throughout the film. Various films such as the Godfather are also parodied. The film does not have as clever or an original premise such as some of the other Pixar films. The concept of a bunch of different animals together seemed all too similar to the many Madagascar films made. As with many Disney films there is an overall good message to leave with the audience, and this one is to always believe in yourself and dreams, and to not judge a book (or an animal) by its cover. The film is well animated, but does not dazzle or leave one in awe. Although there is nothing particularly wrong or glaring with Zootopia, in the sea of animated films that are becoming more and more popular, Disney's Zootopia does not stand out as much as I had hoped. The film is a general crowd pleaser that does not take much risk and simply tries to entertain and that's not always a bad thing. -2.9.2017

There's been alot of buzz surrounding this movie. All year, in fact. People seem to be attracted to this movie because of it's themes of racism, despite it being a "family adventure film". I wonder why that is? Firstly, I find this film to be immensely overrated. It sits on a 98% on Rotten Tomatoes and it seems to be that Zootopia is impossible to hate. Admittedly, it is a great children's film and a movie that adults will also enjoy, and critics seem to agree. This does *not* mean, however, it is a perfect or near-perfect movie. The biggest flaw in Zootopia is that it tries to be a family film, with an underlying theme of racism and prejudice beneath the surface. The problem is, the film lacks a sense of subtlety. This means that the film tries to have its carrot and eat it, giving a lack of focus and a less-than-great performance in each of the areas. The film would have gone better if it had a sense of subtlety but prefers to heighten the mystery just enough to go over kids heads. Another animated movie about the personification of animals, "Fantastic Mr. Fox" managed to nail the balance by using the characters and the theme to build off each other The main character's in Zootopia, a rabbit named Judy Hopps and a fox named Nick Wilde, were the only properly fleshed out characters in the movie. While this makes sense for a buddy-cop film (like this movie is, whether you like it or not) it does not work when you are trying to build a universe, which arguably is one of this film's biggest priorities. Though the chemistry (no pun intended) between the protagonists is quite charming, the other characters are animal-themed cardboard cutouts of what you've already seen before. This film could have been more ambitious with its ideas and message, however it chooses to focus on its main priorities, almost like a movie check-list that needs to be completed. The story, like the character's, and unfortunately quite cliched and mediocre, which is a real shame as I find the setting quite interesting and creative. It makes sense that this would be the case, however like the characters, it too would have benefited in being more interesting and ambitious. The progression is just what you'd expect from a film of the buddy-cop variety and the editing is just fine, though the twist at the end, which I'm not going to spoil, can be seen from a mile off. Zootopia is a fine, if conventional, animated movie that unfortunately tries a little too hard to be something it's not. Despite all the criticism's I've given it, it still has all the infectious Disney charm that we've come to know and love. Though the characters and story is somewhat cliched, it is built upon and built upon quite well. Kids are gonna love it anyway and adults will probably still enjoy it. All-in-all, 7/10.

I may be the last person on the planet to have finally watched Zootopia, Disney's first quarter hit of the year, and I am very glad that I did. I was expecting something cute with the premise of a plucky rabbit (voiced winningly by Ginnfer Goodwin) joining forces with a wily grifter fox (Jason Bateman) in the big animal metropolis, but what I wasn't expecting was a fully thought out and stupendously imaginative world and a message that is just as thought out and pertinent. The anthropomorphic animal land is filled with colorful locations and plenty of amusing characters. It's highly amusing just to sit back and watch. I knew I was in for something radically different and dare I say more ambitious when there was an N-word approximation joke within the first ten minutes. This was not a moving to be taken lying down. My attention was rewarded with an engaging relationship between the two leads, careful plotting, endlessly clever asides without relying upon an inordinate amount of pop-culture references, and ultimately a noble and relevant message about the power of inclusion, tolerance, and rejecting prejudice. The larger metaphor seems slightly muddied by the late reveal of who is behind the conspiracy to make the animals go feral, but I wouldn't say it undercuts the film's power. The characters charmed me and I was happy that each ecosystem factored into the story in fun and interesting ways. There are plenty of payoffs distributed throughout the movie to make it even more rewarding. Zootopia is a funny, entertaining, heartfelt, and immersive movie with great characters and a world I'd like to explore again. Given its billion-dollar success, I imagine a return trip will be in short order and we should all be thankful. Something this spry and creative needs to be appreciated. Nate's Grade: A

Surprisingly political of a children's movie has a bunny rabbit from the country travel to the big city with dreams of being the first bunny on the police force. But once she gets on the force she encounters condescension from her superiors, not really listened to, and is generally seen as a political stunt by the mayor. Our bunny rabbit heroine, who's a not so subtle stand-in for women's rights, then enters a city that is not as terrific as she imagined. She finds stores refusing service to certain species, she finds a city that's segregated by animal types, and general open discrimination and negative views of certain animals (they even talk about certain animals being biologically predisposed to be savages). But that all is the intelligent subtext of a film that on the surface level is funny, populated with charming characters, and a visual delight. Our bunny rabbit heroin, voiced by Ginnifer Goodwin, begins investigating a rash of animals turning savage. She enlists the help of a con man fox, voiced by Jason Bateman, who has a bit of a chip on his shoulder by how most residents of Zootopia view foxes. There are also some very funny voice work by Idris Elba as a police captain, Bonnie Hunt as Goodwin's mother, Tommy Chong as a stoner water buffalo, J.K. Simmons as the mayor, Alan Tudyk as a sketch weasel, and you even get Shakira, Tommy 'Tiny' Lister, and Kristen Bell in bit parts. This is one of those films that works for both kids and adults and is a must see.

A remarkably timely critique of stereotypes and fear of those who are different, Zootopia offers a lot of laughs for those who miss the connection to our current political climate. While the movie comes across as preachy at times, it does acknowledge that "life is messy" -- that dreamers must confront reality.

Judy Hopps is a young rabbit with dreams of one day becoming a police officer. No rabbit has ever been a police officer, but Judy perseveres and succeeds. Now she is off to Zootopia, a multi-animal society where all animals, predator and prey, live in harmony. Her euphoria and idealism is short-lived, however, as she discovers that prejudice between species still exists, and she even starts to doubt her anti-stereotyping stance. What's more, she's assigned to parking meter duty... Wonderfully original. The idea of animals harmoniously coexisting in one world, and essentially representing characters that humans would usually take, on has been done (Jungle Book, Robin Hood) but to this extent. Some great little in-jokes and use of the different characteristics of the different animals. Nice story too, with some very engaging plots and characters. Some clever pop-cultural references too (eg The Godfather, Breaking Bad). Behind it all is a great anti-prejudice, anti-racism message which is conveyed very effectively. Maybe a little too effectively in that it is laid on a bit thick and comes across as preachy. A bit more subtlety was in order, though, for kids, the target demographic of the movie, the level was probably about right. Voice casting is spot on, with a host of stars contributing: Ginnifer Goodwin, Jason Bateman, Idris Elba, Tommy Chong (as a stoner, of course!), JK Simmons, Octavia Spencer, Alan Tudyk, Shakira, Bonnie Hunt.

Every Bunny Wants to Make a Difference One of the best animated Disney productions in years, Zootopia is an insightful, hilarious film that entertains audiences while telling its story with ease and empathy. Parents and children will fall in love with the niche personalities we've come to expect from Disney animated films, yet Zootopia teaches valuable lessons of tolerance, acceptance, consideration, and basic "human" sympathy. Directors Bryon Howard and Rich Moore don't fall short of expectations with their high-spirited, good-humored film Zootopia. Ginnifer Goodwin's audacious performance of Judy Hops, an ambitious bunny who is determined to make the world a better place, attracts all audience members that are looking to have a good laugh while becoming engulfed in a zoological world of action and mystery. An eager, young bunny named Judy Hops is in pursuit of leaving behind her uninspiring life of living on a carrot farm to become a police officer in the chaotic city of Zootopia where all forms of animal life (and their ecological environments) are supposedly able to live together in harmony. After graduating at the top of her class from the police academy, Judy has high expectations of becoming the hero that she has always dreamt of. However, that dream is put on hold as she ends up being assigned to the not so thrilling life of a meter made. While performing what seem like meaningless tasks she is confronted by a swindling fox named Nick (Jason Bateman) who may have some crucial information relating to a top priority missing mammal case within the city. Judy and Nick end up becoming perfect examples of how opposites are able to attract by working together to solve the missing mammal case despite only having 48 hours to do so. Racing against the clock, Judy and Nick team up to save the city and identify the culprits. Disney movies oftentimes, are harshly criticized based on there appearance. However, Zootopia is able to portray a conclusive and inspiring message to its audience members which enables each person's imagination to be explored from the outside in. The insightful messages that are portrayed throughout this film are ones that desperately need the attention of society even if they are conveyed in cartoon form. This film is one that is going to have "Every Bunny" wanting to make a difference in there lives and in the lives of those around them.

Zootopia: A change in Animation Zootopia doesn't just give the viewers a simple lesson or just some entertainment for young children 8 years and up. The film Zootopia is very different from other Walt Disney Studio films, such as Frozen and Wreck-it Ralph. It shows a different, but much unexpected, plot that is displayed to the audience. From the missing mammals vanishing and a rookie cop befriending a slick fox to help out with the case, this film offers so much more than just a simple Disney movie to have children sing along. However, for a family movie, Zootopia touches base on so many levels of comprehension that engages the viewer in suspense and excitement. Nevertheless, the film gives children a sense of accomplishing what they want to do when they grow up, just as the character Judy Hopps did. Furthermore, this isn't the only great thing about the film. From the films explicit beauty and rarely seen techniques, Zootopia is a very authentic film and creative film. The films major city, Zootopia, includes 12 unique ecosystems, such as the tundra, the rain forest, and urban environments. The rain forest was very green with very large trees. From the trees were sprinklers that looked like tree branches. When the main character (Judy Hopps played by Ginnifer Goodwin) looked down, you can see various species of animals, such as zebras, elephants, and tigers, walking with very colorful umbrellas. The setting was very calm and exciting. Each ecosystem had its own weather and every animal from predator to prey was welcomed in each ecosystem. The tiny animals, such as mice, had their own gated community, with their tiny markets and shopping centers, such as Mousy' (which is in reality Macy's) and trains, but they are still welcomed outside of their community. The way everything is set up in the movie was so awe-inspiring that it actually makes you smile in amazement. But that's not the only thing that's amazing. The relativity of the film brings together real life events or situations so well. Roxana Hadadi observes that, "The friction felt between the disenfranchised prey species and the more-powerful predator species in a society that is built to favor the latter certainly brings to mind questions about a race and power that have been in the news over the past few years." The movie displayed some stereotyping with terms, such as calling a bunny cute or touching the hair on a sheep. Nevertheless, Judy Hopps was stereotyped for her size because everyone on the force was large and muscular, such as an Elephant, Polar Bear, Wolf, Rhino, Tiger, and/or Cheetah and a bunny was no use to them. She was even seen as the most hated person in the law enforcement due to her job, which was the lowest job to be given. Even though she was ranked at the top of her class in the police academy and was chosen to be assigned to Precinct 1, city center by the Mayor himself, that didn't matter to the Chief of the Precinct at all. The Chief didn't want a bunny at his Precinct at all. But that's not all the film has displayed. In the film, diversity began between the prey and predators. There has, also, been protest being shot on the News about the situation that has been going on in Zootopia among the predator family's biology and of what Judy Hopps had stated about it. Further, in the protest, a prey had harshly insulted a predator verbally. For example, one prey has said to a cheetah that was protesting for peace among prey and predator in Zootopia with other predators and prey, saying, "Go back to the Rainforest!", and the cheetah responded back, saying, "I'm from the Savannah!" Judy Hopps knew that she had to fix Zootopia at that point. The film is no ordinary film where the Hero is always successful, instead, the Hero has problems as well. Roxanna Hadadi describes Judy Hopps character as, "idealistic, driven, with a chip on her shoulder that drives her to help the underdog, she's a perfect hero," then she continues to add, "Until you realize that she has shortcomings, misconceptions, and stereotypes just like anyone else." Nevertheless, the character of Judy Hopps was always determined to prove herself, stating to the chief of the Precinct, "I caught the bad guy...I want to be a police officer." Roxana Hadadi emphasizes that, "To prove to her doubting family and skeptical colleagues that she's picked the right career, Judy volunteers to help find one of the 14 missing mammals. With 48 hours from her boss to crack the case, she needs Nick's knowledge of Zootopia's inner workings and underworld- whether he wants to help or not." Judy Hopps basically had to find the missing mammal before the 48 hours were up or she will have to resign. Stacking her job on the case. Some may challenge the view of the character's role. Even claiming that the characters in the film are jokes. However, this claim carries little weight, due to the scene in the film of Judy Hopps taking her police training seriously and proving to her doubting parents and colleagues that she can become a police officer and she did. That scene shows determination and determination isn't a joke at all. Though a viewer, J. Olson, may point out that, "in the world of Zootopia all DMV workers are sloths," that isn't exactly the type of joke others are thinking about. Many people that go to a DMV has to wait in line for a long time and in the film, by putting sloths in the DMV shows that exactly. That scene there is to entertain the audience, and is possibly saying that those working in the DMV can be compared to sloths. Roxana Hadadi claims that, "Zootopia does a good job fleshing out Hopps so fully that you can't help but root for her." Of course, many will probably disagree that the film Zootopia is a funny film with some action. However, this argument seems to ignore the pros of the film which is supported by Roxana Hadadi by stating, "As nuanced as that exploration in in Zootopia, there are other elements of the film that feel surprisingly dated, like a subplot lifted directly from 'The Godfather' and a character modeled after Snooki from the MTV reality show 'Jersey Shore'." Then she goes on to state that, "Those flaws keep Zootopia from perfection, but what it does pull off- from its excellently actualized main characters to how it addresses current polices- is mighty impressive enough." Though a film is not perfect in every way, the upsides is what makes the film extremely exquisite. Even though J. Olson states, "The funny thing about Walt Disney Animation Studios Zootopia is that it isn't that funny, or straightforward, or anything moviegoers have come to associate with Disney brand," this film wasn't technically made to be straightforward, however, it was made to entertain and provide a lesson to the audience. If the film was straightforward like other unanimated movies, then the film wouldn't be very entertaining to the audience, instead, it wouldn't be a Walt Disney Animation at all. Being said, Zootopia is a very artistic movie with an outstanding approach to society. Instead of a baby movie that targets children from the ages 8 years old and below, the movie gives each age group a little taste of excitement. The bunny cop and the sneaky fox was a great touch; making the characters acceptable to the audience, especially the children, but with maturity in their actions. It seems to show reality in child's perspective, but have deeper meaning in an adult's view point. The film also makes an amazing approach in the climax that grasps the viewers' attention due to the suspenseful attitude in the musical selection. The structure of the film and the roles of the characters makes this a "To See" movie for all age groups. In retrospect, it's rather incredible that Zootopia currently stands as the number two box office film of 2016 with over a billion dollars in ticket sales. Frankly, a movie this on the nose about hard hitting political topics shouldn't have even been able to make it out of the gates, much less into family audiences but somehow, Zootopia cracked every nut. I know hardcore conservative families and everyone in between and they have all loved this film. And don't get me wrong, Zootopia is charming, funny and well made with a bevy of hilarious pop culture references that are expertly crafted. However, at the same time, Zootopia is a straight up cultural critique, both of the blatant racism of the right and the delusional talk only attitude of the left. Get past the cute fuzziness and this movie is a savage, incredibly clever and exceptionally well timed critique aimed at voters and party bigwigs on both sides right as we nosed into election year. Incredibly, in a rare testament to corporate Disney's brainchild, the movie is original, enjoyable and a thinker all at the same time. I won't poke too hard at the analogy or read too much into Disney's ulterior motives because ultimately, I think this movie really needed to be made regardless. In a rapidly shifting culture where our youngest members are increasingly our most tolerant, it seems only fitting that our most accessible theater content would also reflect that progressive nature. Bravo Hollywood, bravo.

Disney Does it Again With Zootopia! The Disney film Zootopia is set in a world where animals have evolved and now live much like humans do. The film Zootopia centers on the rabbit with a big dream, the up beat, lovable, Judy Hopps, voiced by Ginnifer Goodwin (Walk the Line, Once Upon a Time). Judy Hopps was a small town rabbit with dreams of being a respected and loved police officer, who moves to the city Zootopia. While Judy is indeed successful in becoming a cop, notably the first ever rabbit to do so, she is still overlooked by everyone, including Police Chief Bogo, voiced by Idris Elba (Pacific Rim, The Jungle Book) and assigned to parking duty. However, Judy takes it upon herself to begin an investigating. A series of local disappearances, Judy needs the help of Nick Wilde, voiced by Jason Bateman (Starksy and Hutch, Horrible Bosses), a con artist fox she had previously encountered. With her job on the line, the two begin to discover the disappearances in Zootopia are tied into a conspiracy and a cover-up involving some locals. "The Big D", better known as Disney has 80 years or more of experience making animated films, so saying that Disney has made another family film is not anything particularly noteworthy. It is what we have come to expect. While best known for their musicals, princesses, and prince charming, Disney animation has been on a roll of late with animated movies with a message. Like the Academy Award winning Big Hero 6 and Wreck-It Ralph. However, Zootopia is not simply another fun Disney animated movie. It is one of the greatest Disney animated movies I have seen in the last ten years. From a technical standpoint, Zootopia is top notch. The animation is gorgeous. All of the animals look spectacular. Each creature looks alive, real, and emotional on screen. Action scenes are fun, exciting, and a joy to watch. I have not seen Disney to great-animated action sequences like this since Toy Story 2. The action scenes will have you gasping, on the edge of your seat, and invested in the moment. The world is so colorful, bold, and a world you actually want to invest in. Accordingly, the voice cast works well. In addition to Ginnifer Goodwin and Jason Bateman we get the talents of J.K. Simmons (Spider-Man, Whiplash), Idris Elba, and musical artist Shakira, among others. Every actor and character is perfectly matched! To Heavy of a Message for a Kids Film? The story is so much more than just a buddy cop film, between a fox and a rabbit. The film is clever, has great inside reference jokes, there are a lot of jokes for adults that will go way over kids' head (references to The Godfather, the DMV, and Breaking Bad, for instance), but there's plenty for younger audiences to laugh at, too, and it all comes wrapped in great messages about courage, empathy, tolerance, teamwork, and the dangers of reducing others to stereotypes. I know this is a kid's movie, and this may not be politically correct. But, this movie has cojones (I'm talkin' 'bout balls)! For a kid's film to tackle on the subject of race, stereotypes, relations, profiling, discrimination and bullying is really brave. Everyone can connect to this movie, and that what makes it beautiful. You can view it multiple times, and still learn something new. Something new about yourself, something new about society, some new jokes, overall something amazing every time for kids and adults. My only complaint about this film is, for a kid's movie, it is a little lengthy. Also, I am not sure if kids will understand the entire message, and laugh as much as they would like to. So these are my final Bitchin' Buddha thoughts on the film Zootopia. It is Clever and heartwarming, it has vibrant visuals, an amazing storyline, and a message for the world. A message that we as a society cannot fully grasp, but an animated movie helps us along the way. This is why I like movies. They teach, inspire, and make us connected. Also, Shakira plays a singing pop star Gazelle in the movie. I thought I would never say this, but that was a sexy gazelle! I believe the Disney film Zootopia earns a... 5/5! Thank you all for reading and or viewing, and I hope you all have an amazing day as always. :)
